text:
Is there a name for optimization but you don't have an objective but you have an Oracle which you query to compare solutions and get the best of the bunch?
The Oracle doesn't have to impose a total and strict ordering but it is transitive.
The variables making up the objects can be real valued, integer valued or categorical.
Constraints might be (partially) know without querying an oracle.

Or something like that.

elements.text:
Is there a name for optimization but you don't have an objective but you have an Oracle which you query to compare solutions and get the best of the bunch?
The Oracle doesn't have to impose a total and strict ordering but it is transitive.
The variables making up the objects can be real valued, integer valued or categorical.
Constraints might be (partially) know without querying an oracle.

Or something like that.

text: So you give a number of candidates to the oracle, eg, x1, x2, ... (here each x is a vector), and it returns which is the “best” (eg x3) among all the trial points?

elements.text: So you give a number of candidates to the oracle, eg, x1, x2, ... (here each x is a vector), and it returns which is the “best” (eg x3) among all the trial points?

text: Evolutionary/genetic algorithms should be compatible with your requirements. There’s probably more concrete stuff, but you might want to search around <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_algorithm>

attachments.title: Evolutionary algorithm
attachments.text:
In computational intelligence (CI), an evolutionary algorithm (EA) is a subset of evolutionary computation, a generic population-based metaheuristic optimization algorithm. An EA uses mechanisms inspired by biological evolution, such as reproduction, mutation, recombination, and selection. Candidate solutions to the optimization problem play the role of individuals in a population, and the fitness function determines the quality of the solutions (see also loss function). Evolution of the population then takes place after the repeated application of the above operators.
Evolutionary algorithms often perform well approximating solutions to all types of problems because they ideally do not make any assumption about the underlying fitness landscape. Techniques from evolutionary algorithms applied to the modeling of biological evolution are generally limited to explorations of microevolutionary processes and planning models based upon cellular processes. In most real applications of EAs, computational complexity is a prohibiting factor. In fact, this computational complexity is due to fitness function evaluation. Fitness approximation is one of the solutions to overcome this difficulty. However, seemingly simple EA can solve often complex problems; therefore, there may be no direct link between algorithm complexity and problem complexity.

elements.text: Evolutionary/genetic algorithms should be compatible with your requirements. There’s probably more concrete stuff, but you might want to search around

text:
Ideally for a EA you want the n-best, rather than 1.
Don't need them in order though.

elements.text:
Ideally for a EA you want the n-best, rather than 1.
Don't need them in order though.

text:
But could probably make it work with just 1.
If it's too expensive to ask the Oracle multiple times (if it is cheap then you can get the Oracle to  do run- offs)

Using evolutionary algorithms is an obvious approach for this but i can imagine other algorithms.
